sections.text: When negative adverbials (never, rarely, seldom, not only, not once) start a sentence, invert the subject and auxiliary verb. Add DO/DOES/DID if there's no auxiliary.

sections.structure: Negative adverbial + auxiliary + subject + main verb

examples.original: I have never seen such beautiful scenery before.
I will not go to that restaurant again.
She rarely complains about anything.
We have seldom experienced such poor service.
He had never felt so happy before.
She not only sings but also dances professionally.
I have rarely enjoyed a film so much.
They will never forget this experience.
She seldom visits her hometown anymore.
We have not only finished early but also saved money.
examples.after: early, but we have also saved money.

sections.text: Use inversion with strong negative expressions: at no time, in no way, under no circumstances, by no means, on no account, on no condition.
These structures are very formal and emphatic, often used for prohibition or strong denial.

examples.original: I did not say you could borrow it at any time.
We cannot smoke in here under any circumstances.
I do not blame you for this accident in any way.
It is not easy to master this skill by any means.
You must not reveal this information under any circumstances.
Students should not use this exit on any account.
Customers should not be allowed to enter this area on any condition.
She has not mentioned leaving at any time.
We will not accept late submissions on any account.
This is not the end of the matter by any means.

sections.text: When 'only' + time expression starts a sentence, invert the subject and auxiliary in the MAIN clause (not in the 'only' clause).
The inversion happens AFTER the 'only' clause: Only when he explained it DID I UNDERSTAND.

examples.original: I understood inversion only when he explained it.
It started raining only after I had left.
I understood the problem only then.
She realized her mistake only when she saw the results.
examples.before: Only when she saw the results

examples.original: We can solve this problem only by working together.
She discovered the error only after she had submitted the report.
examples.before: Only after she had submitted the report

examples.original: He understood the importance only after it was too late.
examples.before: Only after it was too late

examples.original: You will succeed only through hard work.
They appreciated what they had only when it was gone.
She realized her mistake only later.

sections.text: Use No sooner...than, Hardly...when, Scarcely...when for immediate sequences. Use Not until for delayed actions.
No sooner uses THAN. Hardly/Scarcely use WHEN. Use past perfect in the inverted clause.

examples.original: He had arrived, and the meeting started immediately.
We had gone to bed, and the phone rang immediately.
examples.after: to bed than the phone rang.

examples.original: She had sat down, and the phone rang immediately.
I had entered the room, and everyone stopped talking immediately.
examples.after: the room when everyone stopped talking.

examples.original: We did not get home until midnight.
She did not understand until he explained it.
They had arrived, and the storm broke immediately.
I did not realize the problem until it was too late.
examples.before: Not until it was too late

examples.original: She had left, and it started raining immediately.
He did not feel better until he took the medicine.
examples.before: Not until he took the medicine

sections.text: Use 'not since' + time reference to emphasize how long it has been since something happened.
Typically uses present perfect or past perfect with inversion.

examples.original: I have not felt so happy since I was a child.
examples.before: Not since I was a child

examples.original: She has not visited us since 2010.
We have not seen such a good performance since last year.
I have not eaten so much since I was a teenager.
examples.before: Not since I was a teenager

examples.original: He has not played so well since his injury.
They have not been so busy since they opened the shop.
examples.before: Not since they opened the shop

examples.original: She has not studied so hard since university.
I have not been so worried since the accident.

sections.text: Emphasize 'so' or 'such' at the beginning by inverting subject and verb. Formal and literary style.
So + adjective/adverb + BE/auxiliary + subject OR Such + BE + noun phrase

examples.original: The view was so beautiful that we stayed for hours.
She spoke so fondly about her parents.
He worked so hard that he fell ill.
The problem was so complex that nobody could solve it.
It was such a beautiful day that we went to the beach.
examples.answer: was the beauty of the day
examples.after: that we went to the beach.

examples.original: She sang so beautifully that everyone was moved.
His anger was such that everyone left the room.
The storm was so severe that all flights were cancelled.

sections.text: In formal English, remove 'if' and invert: Had = If + past perfect, Were = If + past simple, Should = If + should.
Very common in formal and literary English, business writing, and formal speech.

examples.original: If I had known, I would have helped you.
If she were here, she would know what to do.
examples.after: , she would know what to do.

examples.original: If you should need help, call me.
If we had left earlier, we wouldn't have missed the train.
examples.after: earlier, we wouldn't have missed the train.

examples.original: If I were rich, I would travel the world.
If she should arrive early, tell her to wait.
If he had listened to advice, he wouldn't be in this situation.
examples.after: to advice, he wouldn't be in this situation.

examples.original: If it were not for your help, I would have failed.
examples.after: for your help, I would have failed.

examples.original: If we should hear any news, we'll let you know.
examples.after: any news, we'll let you know.

examples.original: If they had known about the problem, they would have fixed it.
examples.after: about the problem, they would have fixed it.

sections.text: Use 'nowhere' for strong negative emphasis about place. Use 'little' to mean 'hardly/barely'. Both require inversion.
These structures are formal and emphatic, adding drama to writing and speech.

examples.original: You cannot find a city as beautiful as Funchal anywhere.
examples.after: a city as beautiful as Funchal.

examples.original: They did not know what awaited them.
You will not see such scenery anywhere else.
She did not realize the impact of her decision.
We could not find better service anywhere.
I did not expect to see you here.
She has not been happier anywhere else.
He did not imagine that he would become famous.
They had not found such hospitality anywhere before.
We did not suspect that he was lying.
